My Musically Minded Family

I am the youngest of three brothers and the only girl in my family. My mom died when we were young so it has been up to my dad to raise us. My brothers all followed in my father's footsteps and have entered the music business in one way or another. Whether producing their own records or looking at audio engineering colleges, we have all inherited our dad's musical talent and passion.

My oldest brother, named Timothy after my dad, just got engaged to a great lady named Lucy. Together, they run a music store in our home town. They sell everything music from instruments to recordings on vinyl, CDs and cassette tapes. In our town, their shop is the number one place people go for anything music related.

Lucy offers lessons in the back of the store to kids and adults alike. On Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays you can see elementary and middle school kids trooping into the back room to learn to sing and play the piano. My brother plays the guitar and offers lessons now and then when he has time off from running the store.

Ralph is my second oldest brother. He has his heart set on being a film soundtrack composer for big time Hollywood feature films. He just graduated from college and is headed for a Masters degree next. This is all just part of the process of getting him his dream job.

Gabriel is the brother I am closest to. He is just a few years older than me and in his sophomore year of college. He hasn't settled on a major yet but he would most like to teach music theory at a college level. For him, too, that means quite a few more years of college level training before he is ready to teach.

As for myself, I play the piano and guitar just like my family taught me. I also sing and am training with Lucy to improve my voice further. I just graduated from high school and am choosing to take a few years off before diving into college. Since I know I want to go into the music biz and am already surrounded by it, I feel like it makes sense to stay put until I am more sure about my future plans.

At the moment, I work at my oldest brother's music store and can't imagine a life where I am not surrounded my music, musical instruments and musicians. Since this has been my whole life, I am sure I will end up somewhere surrounded by music when I do pick a career.

The latest thing I have become interested in is being an engineer of sorts. I have always been fascinated by radio in all forms so maybe that kind of college training is in my future. I have been looking at audio engineering colleges and am already getting excited about what all I could learn there once enrolled.

Doing Something Beats Doing Nothing

Millions of people in the United States have been adversely affected by the economic downturn, and one of the aspects of current conditions that does the most psychological damage is the prevailing feeling that things aren't ever going to get better. That creates a sense of urgency, which keeps people from using the downtime they have during a period of unemployment to enrich their lives. Rather than enrolling in art or music production schools, for example, they are fretting about their economic frustrations.

Economies move in cycles of expansion and contraction, and the contraction we're experiencing now was overdue when it came. The economic fundamentals of contraction were already beginning when the tech bubble burst; after that the economy was propped up artificially on the back of a real estate boom that was driven, it turned out, by hot air.

When things finally gave, the shock was extreme because contraction had eroded away the support beneath what we thought were sound dynamics. it took us some time, especially since we were distracted by political change, to realize how significant the contraction was, and it will still take some time for expansion to take over. Even when it does, it's unlikely we'll get back to where we were because the world has changed. Wealth has spread out across more of the world, and the American economy isn't special anymore.

Thanks to political opportunism, it's hard to see anything but negative. It seems that the entire political spectrum is united in its effort to blame somebody else for the downturn; and in the process nearly everyone makes the problems seem as big as possible. While all that sound and fury isn't doing anybody any good, it does distract us from finding a silver lining in all of this.

Ultimately, the effects of agenda-pushing during this time will probably have more of an impact on slowing the road to recovery than all of the bad financial decisions we made. And if there's any justice history will, someday, judge the political masterminds of today with great and well-deserved harshness for putting personal and ideological agendas ahead of the basic needs of hundreds of millions of their countrymen. In the present, however, they are not judged harshly. Instead, they have the public ear, and into it they're whispering vitriol and dire prophesies.

For a guy who's lost his job and is struggling to find another, all the political rhetoric in the wind these days doesn't instill confidence. It instills fear. It predicts a darker tomorrow when we're already staring at a pretty bleak today, and that has the effect of sucking the wind out of our sails. It robs us of hope. It makes it more difficult for us to see opportunities because they're hidden in the thicket of cynicism.

Anybody who is unemployed today should be looking at the future in large terms seizing whatever opportunity there is. That's how we regain momentum as individuals, and the collective effect of that momentum is the driving force that turns contraction into expansion. Seizing opportunity means changing our attitude from static negativity to active positivism.

That means doing something. It really doesn't matter what it is as long as it's something productive. Checking out music production schools and enrolling in classes doesn't get you a job, but it starts the ball rolling; it gets you productive again. As soon as we get productive, good things start to happen. That's another way in which the economy is cyclical.
